comments.commentBody: Actually, when someone thrusts himself or herself in someone else's face and talks at them, with permission, it's harassment -- especially when that person is arriving for a medical procedure of any type.

One should be allowed sufficient "personal space" to literally walk to a facility and through the door to have a health-related procedure without encountering some fanatic who disagrees with your having that procedure. The court has literally allowed an intruder into your life and decision making by making it legal for an unsolicited, self-appointed counselor to talk you out of something.

'Chief Justice Robert’s opinion does not discuss that ruling. It narrowly focuses on the law’s challengers, whom it characterized as offering “counseling and information,” and engaging in “personal, caring, consensual conversations.”

Those who thrust themselves into someone else's life at an abortion facility, a stranger no less, are not performing counseling but rather trying to shame or intimidate women into walking away from a possible abortion. @ Reynolds & Counter & JoanneN — Your dismissal of the exceptionally high all-around competitiveness of Group G is unconvincing. Measuring that quality for purpose of comparing the different groups is problematic, of course; the FIFA rankings are a suspect tool for doing so, though they probably can give a rough sense of where teams stand in the world hierarchy.

I think the most illuminating measure of the overall quality of Group G is Paul's (Bellerose Terr.) observation: Group G is the only first-round group in World Cup •history• in which each team in the group advanced from the first round of play in the •previous• World Cup tournament.

JoanneN argues that Group D should have been regarded as the most competitive of this tournament's groups, because it included "two former world cup winners." Actually, all •three• of Costa Rica's opponents in Group D had won the World Cup; I'm not sure which one she might have overlooked in that category.

Nevertheless, while superficially impressive, that's a weak argument with respect to the •current• strength of the teams in the group. Italy's most recent Cup championship, in 2006, is close enough that it might rationally be taken as relevant to the quality of their current national team. But, as I've noted before, the most recent WC titles for England (1966) and Uruguay (1950), while cherished in memory, are sufficiently remote in time that reference to them compels the response, "And what have you done for us •lately•???"

— Brian

I was talking about our two-day class. The professor from Japan was great. We arrange a style with three branches. To convey the feeling of each branch he said to think of them as: 1) a beautiful woman whose husband worked around the clock and didn't come home very often, 2) a handsome young male dancer who did tai chi in Union Square every morning and 3) the woman's puppy, which she walked past Union Square on a fateful morning.

This was all the setup for today's lesson on a more complicated style that is derived from the first one. We were to imagine that we directed a play about the woman, the dancer and the puppy and it did so well that we were asked to turn in into an opera. The first new branch was her husband.

The ACA is a great place to start, but the underlying problem is that it's essentially the camel of a horse put together by a committee.  The parties who had to come to the table to create a policy which would be beneficial to people, enactable by employers and states, without bringing huge losses to the insurance industry, were bound to synthesize only a watered-down version of an ideal.  There are aspects of Healthcare reform for everyone to point fingers at and bemoan, but it's an important statement of national priorities that the law is there at all, even if it is being criticized.

Reality doesn't seem to matter in America any more. For decades Americans have been spending far more than other wealthy countries for a private health care system that yields immense profits and short, sick lives. A trillion wasted each year. For nothing.

The ACA is reducing costs, cutting premiums, lowering the numbers of uninsured by 70 per cent in medicaid expansion state, terminating the lifetime limits death panels and cruel pre-existing conditions scam, ending junk insurance etc. A success on all fronts. Doesn't matter.
